current_fact.fact_text: When 'Jana Gana Mana' was first sung in 1911, some listeners misunderstood it as praise for a British monarch. Tagore later clarified that its 'Ruler of the Minds of People' was not a king, but a spiritual, universal guiding presence—showing how lyrics can carry layered meanings, especially in political times.

episode.title: Sedna FM #01 - November Bomb
episode.description: The first Family & Friends radio episode from Yasmin Sarbaoui and Gaia Parolini. Where it all began — a life soundtrack that launched Sedna FM into the universe. Raw, heartfelt, and full of the energy that defines everything that followed.
songs: Canserbero - De la vida como pelicula, tragedia, comedia y ficcion

current_fact.match_reason: An anthem’s layered, contested meaning pairs with the station’s first ever episode—a foundational mix about voice, identity, and how songs can mean different things to different people.

published.fact_text: In 2004, a colossal flare from the magnetar SGR 1806-20 briefly outshone almost everything in the sky, releasing more energy in a tenth of a second than the Sun emits in 100,000 years. Earth's atmosphere absorbed the blast, but satellites and instruments picked up the brightest extrasolar event ever recorded.

episode.title: Morning Drops #03 - Space Shift
episode.description: Gaia invites you to shift your mindset with a simple yet powerful reflection: What if we saw emptiness not as a void but as space to create? An energising and feel-good selection of tracks, the perfect way to ease into your day and set the tone for the week ahead.
songs: Willy J Healey - Woke Up Smiling
The Strokes - You Only Live Once

published.match_reason: A cosmic, mind-bending space event resonates with an episode about reimagining emptiness as creative space and shifting perspective.

published.fact_text: When Apollo 8 splashed down on December 27, 1968, it marked the safe return of the first humans to orbit another world. During the mission, the crew captured the iconic 'Earthrise' photograph, transforming how humanity saw its home planet—small, fragile, and shared.

episode.title: Sedna FM #02 - Destination Sedna
episode.description: Continuing the Sedna FM journey together with family and friends! Episode two of the main series — exploring new musical territories and deepening the connection with our listeners. A collective voyage through sound.
songs: Odion Iruoje - Identify With Your Roots
Depeche mode - world in my eyes (Oil Tank Mix)

published.match_reason: A daring voyage around the Moon aligns with an episode themed as a destination journey through sound and new territories.

published.fact_text: The 1939 Erzincan earthquake in eastern Turkey reached an estimated magnitude of 7.8 and a Mercalli intensity of XI, 'Extreme'. Entire neighborhoods were leveled in seconds, and temperatures well below freezing turned the aftermath into a race against both rubble and cold.

episode.title: Morning Drops #05 - Electric Shock
episode.description: An energizing episode with electrifying sounds to wake you up and get you moving. High energy tracks that deliver a jolt of musical electricity to start your day.

published.match_reason: The sudden, devastating force of an earthquake mirrors the jolt and raw power evoked by an 'Electric Shock' rock selection.

published.fact_text: On December 27, 1831, a 22-year-old Charles Darwin boarded HMS Beagle for what was meant to be a routine survey voyage. Instead, his five-year journey through oceans, islands, and strange ecosystems quietly planted the seeds of the theory of evolution by natural selection.

episode.title: Morning Drops #39 - Immerse
episode.description: An analogy between diving, one of Gaia's great passions, and the act of immersing in life itself. A reflection on what happens when we go below the surface: when we let ourselves be fully present. From moments of calm suspension to warm, rhythmic flow, the selection moves like water — fluid, organic, and alive. An invitation to slow down, listen deeper, and float.
songs: Pino D'Angiò - Un Po' d'Uva e un Liquore

published.match_reason: Darwin’s ocean voyage and deep engagement with the natural world pair with an episode about immersion, water-like flow, and going below the surface.

published.fact_text: Radio City Music Hall opened its doors in 1932 as the 'Showplace of the Nation', combining cutting-edge Art Deco design with elaborate stagecraft. Its enormous stage and hidden hydraulic elevators allowed entire sets to rise and vanish like magic, redefining what live entertainment could look like.

episode.title: Morning Drops #12 - 80's Club
episode.description: Starting with a Monday evening in Munich — a few drinks, friends, and landing in an 80s dance party. From Donna Summer's hypnotic pulse, to Depeche Mode's bright synthpop, Ken Laszlo's Italo Disco romance, and Mylène Farmer's darker theatrical world. Four songs, four corners of the 80s — connected by the machines that changed how we dance.
songs: Depeche Mode - Just Can't Get Enough

published.match_reason: A legendary performance hall built for spectacle and dance meshes with an 80s-club-themed episode celebrating stages, lights, and movement.

published.fact_text: The Cave of Swallows in Mexico, first documented by outsiders in 1966, plunges more than 370 meters straight down—taller than the Eiffel Tower. Every morning, thousands of birds spiral out of the darkness in a living vortex, while humans rappel from the rim into the world’s largest known cave shaft.

episode.title: Morning Drops #40 - Diving With Orcas
episode.description: Yasmin's friend Caroline takes us beyond the polar circle, into the Arctic waters of Norway, where orcas and humpback whales gather each winter. A personal journey shaped by a quiet obsession with orcas, from Patagonia to the icy fjords of the north. The soundscape moves gently between cinematic swells and soft, rhythmic pulses — echoing the cold light of Arctic mornings and the grace of underwater encounters.

published.match_reason: A vast vertical cavern filled with birds and daring descents echoes the episode’s spirit of entering extreme natural spaces and encountering wild animals up close.

published.fact_text: When 'Show Boat' premiered on Broadway in 1927, it broke with the lighthearted revues of its time by weaving a serious story about race, love, and time into its songs. Its integrated narrative structure helped define the modern American musical, where music and plot are inseparable.

episode.title: Morning Drops #38 - History of Flamenco
episode.description: A special journey into the history of Flamenco, guided by Yasmin and her guest Almudena from Madrid, Spain. Exploring the roots and evolution of this emotionally raw and culturally rich tradition, from its early vocal origins and Andalusian influences, through its transformation on stage and screen, to its modern reinventions by iconic Spanish artists.
songs: La Niña de los Peines - Al Gurugú
Paco de Lucía - Entre dos aguas
Camarón de la Isla - La leyenda del tiempo

published.match_reason: A pioneering musical theatre work pairs with an episode exploring the evolution of another performance tradition deeply tied to stage, emotion, and storytelling.

published.fact_text: In 1911, 'Jana Gana Mana' was first performed at an Indian National Congress session in Calcutta, decades before it became India’s national anthem. Written in Sanskritized Bengali by Rabindranath Tagore, it was crafted to sound timeless and inclusive, resonating across languages and regions.

episode.title: Morning Drops #01 - Timeless Legacy
episode.description: Gaia guides us through timeless music to start the morning with the right foot! The first episode of the Morning Drops series — classic sounds that never fade.
songs: Roberta Flack - Killing me softly with his song

published.match_reason: The birth of a future national anthem fits with an episode centered on songs that feel timeless and enduring across generations.

published.fact_text: Hōshō, commissioned in 1922, was the world’s first ship designed from the keel up as an aircraft carrier rather than converted from another vessel. Its compact flight deck hosted early experiments in takeoff and landing at sea, turning the ocean’s surface into a mobile runway.

episode.title: Morning Drops #20 - Hitchhiking Poland
episode.description: Yasmin takes you back to the summer of 2020, when borders were still uncertain and a long-held wish to visit Poland finally came true. Through four tracks, tracing her journey from a stranger's couch in Poznań to the peaks of Zakopane.

published.match_reason: A pioneering vehicle for long-distance air journeys at sea syncs with an episode about unconventional travel, movement, and crossing borders in new ways.

published.fact_text: In 1999, Burger King recalled millions of plastic Poké Ball toys after several children suffocated or nearly suffocated when the halves sealed over their noses and mouths. It became a strange meeting point between fast food, pop culture, and the evolution of modern product safety standards.

episode.title: Morning Drops #03 - secret_mp3_player_1
episode.description: Inspired by a throwback MP3 player on Instagram, Yasmin and Gaia take you on a nostalgic journey to the early 2000s. LimeWire, eMule, guilty-pleasure playlists — remember those? Hit play and relive the songs that shaped a generation.

published.match_reason: A late-90s Pokémon-themed fast food craze fits with an early-2000s nostalgia episode celebrating the pop culture of that era.

published.fact_text: On December 27, 1996, Taliban forces captured Bagram Airfield, tightening their ring around Kabul and reshaping Afghanistan’s political map. The airbase would later become a symbol of shifting powers, hosting forces from different nations over decades of conflict.

episode.title: Morning Drops #08 - (un)Boxing
episode.description: An episode about breaking free from expectations and labels. Music that helps us unbox ourselves and embrace who we truly are.
songs: Kendrick Lamar - The Blacker the Berry

published.match_reason: A story of power, control, and contested territory aligns with an episode using conscious rap to challenge narratives and break out of imposed boxes.

published.fact_text: In 1949, the Netherlands formally recognized Indonesia’s independence, ending over three centuries of colonial rule under the Dutch East Indies. The struggle that led to this moment mixed diplomacy, guerrilla warfare, and cultural resistance across thousands of islands.

episode.title: Morning Drops #24 - The Rise Of Afrobeat
episode.description: An exploration of the rise of Afrobeat, tracing its roots and evolution as a genre that blends African rhythms with jazz, funk, and highlife. A celebration of the infectious energy and cultural significance of this influential musical movement.

published.match_reason: A major decolonization milestone resonates with an episode focused on Afrobeat, a genre deeply tied to anti-colonial struggle, political voice, and cultural independence.

published.fact_text: The Laws of Burgos, issued in 1512, were the first comprehensive regulations that Spain imposed on its colonists regarding the treatment of Indigenous people in the Americas. While they aimed to limit abuses, they also formalized systems like the encomienda, revealing how law can both restrain and legitimize exploitation.

episode.title: Morning Drops #16 - The Sound of Tuareg
episode.description: A journey into the sound of the Tuareg: from traditional chants and desert rituals to the electrified rhythms of exile and resistance. Music shaped by sand, memory, and survival.

published.match_reason: A colonial legal code affecting Indigenous lives pairs with an episode about a people whose music carries stories of resilience, land, and resistance to imposed systems.

published.fact_text: In 2007, disputed election results in Kenya triggered riots in Mombasa and across the country, spiraling into a wider political and humanitarian crisis. The violence exposed deep ethnic and regional tensions that had long simmered beneath the surface of democratic institutions.

episode.title: Morning Drops #19 - Demystifying Reggaeton
episode.description: Yasmin takes us on a journey through the real story of reggaeton — from its roots in Panama and Puerto Rico to its global evolution. Exploring the genre's history, influences, and cultural impact.
songs: Renato - Chica de los Ojos Café
B. F. Yaviah - Si Tu Quieres Fumar

published.match_reason: An event revealing the complexity behind political narratives connects with an episode unpacking the misunderstood roots and social context of a globally popular genre.

published.fact_text: In 1845, journalist John L. O'Sullivan argued that the United States had a 'manifest destiny' to claim the entire Oregon Country, stretching toward the Pacific. The phrase became a powerful myth justifying westward expansion, mixing idealism, nationalism, and conquest.

episode.title: Morning Drops #39 - Moving Meditation
episode.description: An episode inspired by how travel helps us see more clearly. Stepping into new places opens the mind, shifts perspective. The music moves through balearic warmth, boogie grooves, world and latin-folk influences, and touches of new wave — a selection built to follow the quiet changes that happen when you're out of your usual rhythm.
songs: España Circo Este - Dormo poco e sogno molto
Talking Heads - This Must Be the Place (Naive Melody)

published.match_reason: An ideology of continental expansion is contrasted with an episode about more mindful, reflective journeys that question how and why we move across landscapes.

published.fact_text: The Flushing Remonstrance of 1657, penned by English colonists in what is now Queens, New York, boldly protested a ban on Quaker worship. In a world where religious uniformity was the norm, it argued that 'love, peace and liberty' should extend to people of any faith, foreshadowing later ideas of religious freedom.

episode.title: Morning Drops #34 - Soul Sisters
episode.description: A tribute to four iconic voices — women who have shaped the way we listen, feel, and move. Each track carries a different kind of presence: one that holds you, one that questions, one that grounds, and one that lets go. An energy that is soulful, raw, and unapologetically feminine.
songs: Grace Jones - Walking in the Rain
Aretha Franklin - A Rose Is Still a Rose

published.match_reason: A courageous stand for freedom of conscience fits an episode celebrating powerful voices that challenge norms and insist on the right to be fully themselves.

published.fact_text: Bek Air Flight 2100 crashed shortly after takeoff from Almaty in 2019, when the plane failed to gain proper altitude and struck a concrete structure and a house. The tragedy spurred scrutiny of aging aircraft, training standards, and winter operations in Kazakhstan’s busiest airport.

episode.title: Morning Drops #14 - Slow Planet
episode.description: A pause. A quiet return to slower rhythms, sparked by a live set under the summer sky. A moment to breathe and settle into the week.

published.match_reason: A somber aviation disaster is paired with a gentle, downtempo episode that offers space for quiet reflection and emotional decompression.

published.fact_text: On December 27, 2007, former Pakistani prime minister Benazir Bhutto was assassinated at a campaign rally just weeks before an election, in an attack involving both gunfire and a suicide explosion. As the first woman to lead a democratic government in a Muslim-majority country, her death sent shockwaves through Pakistan and the world.

episode.title: Morning Drops #36 - Women of Rock
episode.description: A tribute to the women who shaped the sound of rock, the ones who picked up a guitar and refused to ask for permission. The conversation unfolds in Italian, led by Gaia and her father. A dialogue between generations and a reminder that the pulse of rock has always belonged to anyone brave enough to play it loud. Distortion, rhythm, freedom.
songs: Joan Jett & The Blackhearts - I Love Rock 'n Roll

published.match_reason: The story of a pioneering female political leader connects with an episode honoring women who broke barriers in another arena dominated by men: rock music.

published.fact_text: Scandinavian Airlines Flight 751, which crashed in Sweden in 1991, lost power in both engines after ingesting clear ice that had formed on the wings and broken off during takeoff. Remarkably, all 129 people aboard survived, thanks in part to a controlled crash-landing in a snowy field and an innovative thrust system that kept some control.

episode.title: Morning Drops #31 - Sailing With Germans
episode.description: From the deck of a sailing boat, hosted by Yasmin and her special guests. A week at sea with six Germans, each with their own stories, songs, and ways of moving through the waves. From shared meals to unexpected laughter, from quiet resilience to sun-soaked joy — a collection of voices and tracks that reflect what it means to journey together.
songs: Ben Howard - Keep Your Head Up

published.match_reason: A dramatic but ultimately survivable crash involving ice and flight reflects the fragility and resilience of travel stories, matched with an episode about shared journeys over unpredictable water.

published.fact_text: By December 27, 1989, the Romanian Revolution had effectively ended as scattered gunfire in Bucharest fell silent and the communist regime collapsed. It was one of the few Eastern European uprisings that turned violently against its leadership, culminating in the swift trial and execution of Nicolae Ceaușescu.

episode.title: Morning Drops #25 - A Trip-Hop Journey
episode.description: Hosted by friend Lorenzo, a journey through the roots and evolution of trip-hop. From Bristol's early experiments with Massive Attack and Tricky, to DJ Shadow's cinematic sampling in California, and Thievery Corporation's global downtempo grooves in Washington D.C. — exploring how this genre blurred boundaries and reshaped electronic music.
songs: Tricky - Hell Is Round the Corner
DJ Shadow - Midnight in a Perfect World

published.match_reason: A dark, cinematic political upheaval matches the moody, boundary-blurring atmosphere of trip-hop, a genre often used to soundtrack tension and transition.

published.fact_text: The same day Romania’s revolution quieted, a massive solar flare from the magnetar SGR 1806-20 would, fifteen years later, briefly alter Earth’s ionosphere—reminding us that even distant cosmic events can touch our skies. For a fraction of a second, the invisible radiation reshaped the way radio waves traveled around our planet.

episode.title: Evening Flows #01 - Yasmin - Crescendo in the Medina
episode.description: The first Evening Flow episode comes from Yasmin. It starts deep in the medina, slow, mysterious, textured, and grows into a liberating dance across sub-Saharan landscapes. A journey through ambient soundscapes, Arabic melodies, Afro-Latin rhythms, and funky highlife grooves.
songs: David Visan & Carlos Campos - Crystal Heart
Evan Mars - Ya Zareef Al Tool
Dele Sosimi & Medlar - You No Fit Touch Am (Medlar Remix)

published.match_reason: A star’s violent outburst altering radio paths fits an evening episode that literally opens with 'Solar Wind' and drifts through cosmic, atmospheric soundscapes.

published.fact_text: Hidden within the Laws of Burgos was a rule that Indigenous people were to be taught Christian doctrine in their own languages, an early nod to linguistic diversity even within an oppressive system. It inadvertently preserved and documented native tongues even as colonization threatened to erase them.

episode.title: Morning Drops #18 - Sardegna
episode.description: Yasmin traces her connection to Sardegna — the island where her Italian journey began. Through music and memory, she shares the story of how this place shaped her family's path, and why it still holds such a deep place in her heart.
songs: Mahmood & Tenores di Bitti - Com’è profondo il mare

published.match_reason: An unexpected space where Indigenous languages persist matches an episode honoring a specific regional culture and language—Sardegna—as a vessel of memory and identity.

published.fact_text: The capture of Bagram Airfield in 1996 didn’t just shift who controlled a strategic runway; it foreshadowed decades in which that same strip of concrete would host wildly different flags. From Taliban fighters to NATO jets, the airfield became a stage where global geopolitics literally took off and landed.

episode.title: Morning Drops #27 - Nomophobia
episode.description: Yasmin reflects on what happened when she recently lost her phone and why it felt freeing. A dive into the psychology of our relationship with smartphones: from nomophobia (the fear of being without a phone), to digital burnout and cognitive overload, to the surprising benefits of boredom and the brain's default mode network. An invitation to rethink how we connect and disconnect.

published.match_reason: A strategic airfield at the center of global power plays mirrors how infrastructure—like our phones and networks—quietly shapes the way we connect, control, and are controlled.

published.fact_text: When 'Jana Gana Mana' was first sung in 1911, some listeners misunderstood it as praise for a British monarch. Tagore later clarified that its 'Ruler of the Minds of People' was not a king, but a spiritual, universal guiding presence—showing how lyrics can carry layered meanings, especially in political times.

episode.title: Sedna FM #01 - November Bomb
episode.description: The first Family & Friends radio episode from Yasmin Sarbaoui and Gaia Parolini. Where it all began — a life soundtrack that launched Sedna FM into the universe. Raw, heartfelt, and full of the energy that defines everything that followed.
songs: Canserbero - De la vida como pelicula, tragedia, comedia y ficcion

published.match_reason: An anthem’s layered, contested meaning pairs with the station’s first ever episode—a foundational mix about voice, identity, and how songs can mean different things to different people.
